reviewText:
Overture is a  top-down bullet hell roguelite. It cites Diablo, Binding of Isaac, and Zelda as inspirations, but the easiest comparison is to Realm of the Mad God. It has almost the exact same gameplay style and even uses the same sprite pack. I'll start this review with a quick pro/con list for those with short attention spans and elaborate on some of those points afterwards. I've also marked each bulletpoint with the paragraph in which I elaborate on them.

PROS:
Fast, kinetic, screen-filling combat (p1)
24 classes, most of which are relatively varied (p3)
Good soundtrack
Dev seems to actually be paying attention to what people say on the forums (p7)
Incredibly difficult (might not be a good thing) (p8)
Permadeath actually causes you to lose something, unlike some games touting roguelike elements (p5)
Fast running mechanic adds a tad of depth, albeit fairly little (p2)
CONS:
Random level generation is essentially window dressing, having very little impact on how you actually play
RPG mechanics are simple and boring (p5)
Overused artwork (p6)
Some bosses don't seem totally balanced, maybe I don't understand them yet (p8)
More cluttered than it needs to be (p2)
Not many bosses or minibosses (p8)
Boring class unlocks (p4)
Cited inspirations might imply this game is something it isn't (p5)

Alright, now for the wordy rambling bits.

1. While similar to Realm of the Mad God in combat, the way you progress through the game is fairly different. RotMG tends to have a slow and fairly boring start as the usual strategy is to farm fairly easy areas up to level 20 and then go into actually difficult areas. Overture is quick and difficult from the start and progresses at a much more enjoyable pace, even if it rarely gives you a chance to breath. By the 4th floor it's already of a fairly absurd difficulty.

2. The combat is quick and more satisfying than I'd expect a game like this to be. There's just something simply enjoyable about wreaking havoc on everying within eyeshot. That said, some classes have skills that make the game nigh incomprehensible, completely filling the screen and destroying any clarity. Most bullet hells tend to increase opacity on your bullets and various other things that can't hit you, since strictly speaking you don't NEED to see them in order to not die. It's a really good way of increasing clarity that this game opts not to utilize. I spent a lot of time deciding whether to give this game a positive or negative review. Overture isn't a bad game, but it definitely isn't a good one.

Overture is a hoard-time grinding game. No, not a dungeon crawler. No, not a puzzle game. No, not an RPG. This is a grinding game. Progressing in this game isn't determined by skill, choices, or even luck, but how much time you're willing to put into this game, which honestly isn't worth it. You will NOT be able to clear this game without grinding for what seems like forever.

You collect gold in each stage, gold is used to unlock/purchase or level up a character of your choice, which becomes more expensive each time. I've only put a little over an hour into this game and even then, I had to force myself to keep playing. The only difference between floors is that enemies have more health as you progress.

Pros    Game is easy to learn to play
Tons of characters to unlock
Music is pretty good
Cons    Only fun if you want to spend hours spam clicking
Characters aren't very different from each other
Game gets old very quickly

It took me an hour to get past the first level of Overture. Hard doesn‚Äôt begin to cover it really. It‚Äôs a fast paced, action ‚ÄòRogue-lite‚Äô, with a lot of monsters, a lot of loot, and not a lot of story. While the game is certainly fun in short bursts, you are going to have to sink a lot of time into it before you can progress.
There are 24 playable classes split up into four types: warriors, rogues, mages and shamans. At the start, you will just have one option from each of the four types, the standard warrior, a ranger, the wizard and the cleric. The others are unlocked using the money you accumulate each time you venture out into one of the randomly generated dungeons. This money is also used to upgrade the attack power of a character once it has been unlocked.
Early on you will probably only be getting a few hundred goal per run, so it‚Äôs quite a limited resource. It seems odd therefore, that money is used both to unlock new characters and upgrade them. If you want to get anywhere in the game, you will need to upgrade a class a fair number of times before it is powerful enough to take on the end boss of each level. This means you will need to unlock a character you actually like playing, which is impossible to know beforehand. If you don‚Äôt get lucky, you will probably end up feeling like you have wasted some of your time, and money, on a class when you could have just been upgrading another one.
That said, the classes aren‚Äôt all that different when it comes down to it. You move around with WASD and attack by using the mouse buttons, where the attacks will go towards your mouse cursor. Right clicking will use your class‚Äô special ability. You will either be up close with a melee weapon or firing from afar with a ranged weapon or a magic spell, but there aren‚Äôt a great many differences between these. You will be safer firing from a distance, but you won‚Äôt be able to make as many hits, so it balances out. However, even the sturdier characters can die pretty quickly in a bad situation.
To get out of a bad spot, you have the ability to run fast. In order to do this, you stop attacking, and run towards your mouse cursor. Dust picks up behind your character and you start hightailing it away. It is a clunky mechanic that could have been improved by just having a button assigned to it. It‚Äôs just too finicky to get right in a high pressure situation. It‚Äôs also not helped by your cursor often being lost in the mayhem on screen. This also hinders you in situations where you need to quickly attack in another direction.
However, when you are in the thick of the action, it is a lot of fun. Damage numbers fly out of enemies and gold and items pour out of corpses and chests in a hugely satisfying fashion. Equipping items is as easy as walking over them and pressing a button. They will be ‚Äòidentified‚Äô when you step on them, and some green or red text will tell you whether it‚Äôs better than what you currently have equipped. It won‚Äôt tell you deeper stats such as special powers, like a weapon which has a chance to reanimate slain enemies to fight for you. But this information can be viewed from a pause screen.
What you get is just the luck of the draw though, so you will sometimes find yourself woefully underprepared for the final boss of each level, and even some of the smaller enemies will pose a tough challenge if they manage to gang up on you. The randomness of loot drops doesn‚Äôt help the overall difficulty. It‚Äôs obviously supposed to be hard, but the difficulty invariably comes from not having the right stats for the fight, rather than based on player skill.
Overture is frustrating at times and has some odd ways of doing things, but when it works, it really works. It takes cues from the likes of Diablo, Zelda and Realm of the Mad God, and there are many reasons for fans of those games to check this one out. Just know that you will be spending a lot of time in the game, and much of it may feel like a grind. There‚Äôs no story, and no other modes to speak of. Thankfully, the action makes up for it in most places.

reviewText:
Firstly, I am not a huge PC gamer. I don't play rogue-likes nor even really understand what that even means, to be brutally honest.

However, it's hard to not fall in love with Overture. There are so many different classes that offer a lot of variety in how you approach the game. The music and sounds are fantastic. The gameplay itself is smooth, fast-paced, rewarding, and frustrating (in a good way).

With that said, the game obviously has some kinks to iron out still (at least, I hope). Difficult games are a thing of the past, and I enjoy the difficulty of this one. The bosses are near impossible... They can hit you, slow you down, and kill you within seconds. It's often not fair, but you can go back for revenge a thousand times over. What I don't like is that loots can spill and spawn into poison swamps or large spike pits. What's the point, really?

Another complaint might be that the difficulty scrolls upwards so incredibly quickly. Floor 1-1 is simple to navigate and make through alive with any class, but to beat the boss and do anything below that floor takes more luck than skill. The blood and whatnot that enemies leave disguise spike traps and other traps on the floor. That isn't real difficulty, that's just being annoying -- and I hope it gets fixed.

I would also like to see more statistics become upgradable in the game. I have one class at Tier 10, and I find the advantage minimal at best. I don't know if armor or items really make that big of a difference, which makes the loot and upgrade system feel a little empty -- which is a huge problem. After playing this game for X number of hours you begin to realize that the developers don't really want to reward you for playing the game, they just want to make it impossible to navigate. It's a little frustrating... Because again, what is the point?

Why have armor when it does nothing? Why collect gold beyond unlocking all of the classes because it feels like it does nothing? Why grind out levels and xp when it does NOTHING. Developers biggest issue is making the game, the items, and the grind feel like it matters... Feel like it all is worth it because your character will kick major ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•. That is lacking right now.

Overall, I wish there was more to do with collected gold and the game keeps track of scrolls for some reason I don't understand yet. It's a fun game that you can sink a few hours into, but right now it's nothing to get too serious about. It's worth the $4 or $5 dollars though.

reviewText: Overture is...an interesting game. It's only a baby step in the right direction for Black Shell Games, but a step nonetheless. I love this game. But I cannot deny that it is flawed and actually oddly enough is being flawed even further. Upon playing build 1.1.1 l had a great time. Sure, many things were unbalanced. Some classes were far better than others. But that was part of the charm Overture brought to the table. But when the developer cranks out an update literally every single day, sometimes two in a day, with a few bug fixes and many class nerfs, that charm fades away. Overture is crazy hard. Only gets worse with each update. I've been playing for 19 hours so far and get slaughtered on the fourth floor. Ten floors in total. Upgrading your character once grants you a 5 damage bonus for each attack you land. 500 gold is added to the upgrade price each time you upgrade. Honestly, l am not very fond of the upgrade system. Hard to call it a system at all. Maybe if you could choose which stat to upgrade instead of attack all the time it would be better. But if you don't get good gear in your run, then happy trails, because you're dead. I don't know what the objective of the dev is. Is it to make the game brutally difficult? If so, mission accomplished. This game defines the grind. You can play for half an hour and have enough for one measly 5 damage upgrade before going off for another half hour. It's ludicrous. I've really enjoyed what a class does and upgraded that character a bunch just to look at the patch notes the next day to see the one aspect l liked about that character revoked. The graphics are pretty nice, they look good. Bright and colorful. But the recycling is so heavy. Bosses are basically just reskins of eachother with one unique attack thrown in. But why do the bosses get so many advantages? For example: Reanimator. Reanimator is a necromancer boss. He rushes you incredibly fast before you have time to dodge, so there goes half your health bar. He summons 2 dragons at once, prepare to be distracted. He summons skeletons, prepare to be annoyed. He is protected by revolving orbs, prepare to stay away. Why on Earth does he do all those things? How about just skeletons and the occasional fireball or two? Oh, and how 'bout the fact that there's ten floors and five bosses. Real good for the Earth, this recycling. The music is the one thing that's pretty much perfect. Props to Rafael Smith. 24 classes in total, and the variety is nice. The nerfs just ruin 'em though. All in all, Overture is a potentially great game ruined by its flaws, made way too hard, and treated like an early access game. If I had to give a verdict, l'd say 6.5 out of 10. I wish l could recommend this game. Good for a few hours, but don't get sucked in. It's too difficult.

reviewText:
Around 1% of the people who bought this game have actually beat it. I am the 99%.

On the one hand, the core of Overture's slash-em-up fantasy bullet hell gameplay (with a great soundtrack to boot) is incredibly addicting. Heck, I'll probably go back to playing it after I finish this review. On the other hand, there's not much else to it. The level are all randomly generated squares where the enemies slowly rush you. The bosses (all of which are simply scaled-up versions of normal enemies) all require exactly the same strategy: kiting in an extremely confined space. The upgrade system is one-dimensional and gets very expensive very fast. Some of the classes are unique and fun, but others are only slight variations on other classes and many are simply not viable if you want to get anywhere in the game.

If you buy this game, you'll probably have a few hours of fun with it. I did. But as you play more and more that feeling that you'll never get beyond the first three floors and are stuck grinding more infinitesimal stat increases that you know, deep down, will never give you the edge to win the game, gradually eats the fun out of the experience.

So, how would I improve Overture?
-Better boss designs that required more dynamic strategies and larger, more varied boss rooms (perhaps with traps?)
-More coherent enemies and map combinations to combat the utter randomness. Being rushed by armies of skeletons, spiders, oozes, yetis, ogres, necromancers AND minotaurs in a single level is ridiculous and completely immersion-breaking, especially when the game has several clear map themes (forest, dungeon, lava, etc.)
-More varied enemy behavior and skills, especially for melee enemies
-Permanent stat increases beyond attack power (health, mana, etc)
-Stat and mechanical improvements for the game's less viable classes (Knight, Invoker, Bandit, etc.)

I'd advise against buying this one. Play Hero Siege, instead.

Both games sort of hinge on the same principle by going overkill with destructibles and number of exploding enemies. Honestly, while this game would have been something neat to see as freeware and a developer's experiment on making a game satisfying to play, it's simply not worth paying for, at all. This is, of course, my opinion - other people seem to be enjoying this, although this game is being given away for free.

They use particle effects, permanent bodies and bloodstaines, screenshake and overall a buttload of money and numbers on the screen to make the player feel overpowered. That aspect is quite nice, although it's very clearly an amateur take on it. With some refinement it could be really satisfying.

Despite having this one nice aspect, the whole game seems like simply filler, and it doesn't do anything new.

The games has probably dozens of classes, which sounds like a lot. However, they mostly play the same. There are only 2 attack: main and special. Special attacks drain mana. The main attacks between classes vary simply in range and power, but they're all essentially the same.
The game has one mechanic: you run faster is you're running in the same direction as the mouse pointer - i.e., you can't aim while running away.
It's an interesting mechanic, for sure!

But the game just swarms you with enemies, it's too zoomed in, attacks are way too big and obfuscating, as are the enemy corpses. Nothing interesting in the environments, you can't see what you're getting hit by, you often get stuck in random terrain that you can't see properly...

It was a fun game to play for 30 minutes. Again, if it was a freeware game like Cactus' or JW's, it would have been cool. The developers gets to create a name for himself while trying something new, and people get a couple of minutes of enjoyment. Once you have to pay for it... it's just not worth it, at all.

Very unpolished and bland, in general. Again, try Hero Siege - not perfect, but far better than this in every respect.

reviewText:
What is it: a generic roguelike with a focus on grinding and some very, very small RPG elements.

Goal: go over 10 floors populated by slight variation of types of enemies and end-of-floor bosses to win.

Pros:
+ Game mechanics are very simple to learn
+ You can spend a few minutes/hours mindlessly killing your time.

Cons:
- The game has zero depth
- Looks apparently impossible but is actually extremely simple after learning two tricks
- After that, it becomes a long, tedious journey keeping the left mouse button (attack) clicked all the time.
- Graphics are very generic
- Monsters can spawn and stay out of the boundaries of the level
- When you win, you are rewarded by a ``victory'' writing enclosed in a square. Really.

At the beginning the game looks very challenging because thousands of enemies come to you and you die very quickly. It looks like the only purpose of the game is you accumulating ``money'' to invest in better characters. However, after you realize that leveling up makes you way stronger than investing money in your character, you can just obtain the right objects to level up fast and grind your way through the floors.

It does not help that, every time you save, you lose your progress on the current floor and have to kill all the enemies again, but keep your level. Thus, you can actually trick the game and become insanely powerful just by loading, killing monsters for a while, saving, starting killing monsters again.

I spent several hours on this while thinking about something else, just for the sake of beating it. So I guess the joke's on me.

Overture has basic pixel-art graphics and a great soundtrack.

You can pick a character from 4 distinct groups and every group contains a few different hero types. After that you're thrown head fisrt into the action. You can move around a medium sized arena and your goal is to descend 10 floors and kill the final baddie. Combat is simple: hold LMB for your basic attack, which can be a quick slash or a stream of fireballs depending on who you chose to play as, and RMB is your hero's stronger ability, for instance the Druid can shapeshift or the Arsonist can randomly lay down flames that continually damage your enemy. There is also a sprint mechanic where you make your character follow the mouse cursor and it will give you a small speed boost as long you don't attack during the sprint.

Action can get a bit hectic, because sometimes there is so much going on screen: enemies, damage numbers, loot, fireballs. It can be a total mess at times, but it won't last longer than a few seconds, either you kill all enemies or the trample you. After the battlefield calms down you can pick up t3h ph4t l3wt left by the enemies. Items like armor to raise your defense, heal you or boost your attack power are all present here.

After you die (this will happen a lot) or beat the game (this takes some practice to do) you will be shown the result gravestone telling you how many enemies you've defeated and how much gold you were able to snatch. Gold can be used to unlock new character classes and permanently increase their attack power - you will need to do this to stand a chance at the later stages of the game.

Final verdict: A simple and hectic hack&slash that can get a bit repetitive, but overall a nice time killer. :>

Overture distills RPG and Roguelike elements to it's core and pulls an addictive little game out of the mix. It's fast pace and though the mechanics are simple enough, it still manage to offer a fairly high skill ceiling experience.

You'll be entering a procedurally generated map where you'll be hacking, shooting, and casting against hordes of enemies. The bosses are often tough and offer a fair degree of variety in strategy. You'll also be collecting money and loot as you travel. Though your loot get reset with every play, the cash you collect carry on, allowing you to purchase new classes and upgrades.

The game is mechanically sound. It's addictive, it's tough, and it mixes it up enough that each play through will offer it's own set of challenges. Where the game lacks a tiny bit is in the visuals. It's by no means ugly, and certainly has it's charm in it's pixel art, it it does look pretty standard issue. I didn't find the art direction to be very memorable. This is one of those games where it's mechanics over graphics".

Overall Overture is a pretty enjoyable little romp

reviewText:
Overture is honestly fast becoming one of my favourite games.

Firstly, I'd describe this game as being simple to control, but nigh on impossible to master. The control scheme is as straightforward as they come, only using WSAD and the mouse, but the difficulty lies in coping with the colossal amount of enemies on each level (supposedly up to 10 levels, but in my first couple of hours, I never got past 2). There are 24 different classes, divided between warriors, archers, mages and shamans, and I found myself using mainly the standard ranger. I did also try some of the others, and it's clear from the get-go that used properly, you can get through swathes of enemies regardless of which class you choose.

There are also power-ups scattered around, which can either be better equipment (letting you deal more damage, increasing mana regeneration etc); or NPCs who follow you around and help you deal damage. As well as this, you can collect gold as you go through the game, and use it to buy new classes or upgrade the ones you already have.

My only slight complaint would be to do with the bosses, which must be killed to progress from level to level. Given that no class has a huge amount of HP, fighting such absurdly tough bosses in such a small room can become frustrating.

Ultimately, this game is brilliantly fast-paced, very punishing (although rarely unfairly so), very well presented in a 16-bit style, and utterly painfully addictive. For ¬£4, you can't go wrong.

reviewText:
If you like Overture, you'll call it a fine example of the action-roguelike genre. If you dislike Overture, you'll call it unremarkable and derivative. Both reviews, I think, are absolutely fair.

As is standard for the genre, you're a pixelated fellow with far too little health and far too many foes, and it's your job to wander through a series of monster-infested fields to find and murder a miniboss guarding a staircase, which will take you to a boss fight. It's played from a top-down perspective and feels at times like a hack-n-slash and at other times almost like a bullet hell.

Gear drops occasionally, and with the exception of the occasional item with a special ability attached to it, each piece of equipment does the same thing; a sword, for instance, will always increast your attack power, while a ring will always increase your mana regeneration. Though shallow, this is good; you absolutely don't have time for any deeper item comparison than figuring out which number is bigger and going with that.

Each class has a (usually) fairly generic left-click main attack aimed towards your mouse cursor, typically some variation on the theme of either a fired arrow or a sword swung mercifully halfway across the screen. Each also has a right-click ability that consumes mana and is unique to its own class; the rogue, for instance, becomes invisible while right click is held, while the Ranger fires a spread of arrows. It's all quite straightforward and follows the equipment system's example of not being a lot, but just enough.

As a longtime fan of Roguelikes, Roguelike-likes, and whatever else you want to call procedurally-generated games that hate you and want you to die, I can tell you that Overture doesn't do anything particularly unique. It's a variation on the themes of its predecessors, and if you've played the Diablos, the Realms of the Mad God, the Zeldas, or the Bindings of Isaac it cites as its inspirations, you're not going to see anything you haven't seen before. However, whether or not it does anything new, Overture does what it does very well.

Ultimately, if you feel like you have enough action-Roguelikes, you can pass this one by; while good, Overture is by no means unmissable. However, if there's room in your life for another entry in the admittedly crowded genre, Overture is a good choice, and I heartily recommend it.

reviewText:
I haven't played this game for too long, as thus haven't gotten very far, but I believe I've grasped how it plays.
This is a light-rogue, hack n' slash, with minimal RPG touches. If you've played them, it will probably remind you of Hero Siege and maybe Quest of Dungeons.

ControlsThe controls for this game are very easy, specially since there are only five actions you can take:
list]
Move (WASD)
Basic attack (LMB)
Special attack (RMB)
Pickup item/ Equip (RMB/F/Space)
Character sheet/ menu (C/esc)There aren't many options to customise this, but they're really not necessary anyway.

DifficultyThat said, although it's easy to get the hand of the controls, winning/ not dying? Not so easy.
The game doesn't have true permadeath, you get to keep the money of your runs and use this to unlock other character classes and upgrade them.
It can be a bit slow at first as you get familiar with the classes and the game. As far as I've gotten it seems progress is slow too for a while (I haven't made it further than the second floor). Luckily though, the floor is randomly generated, so at leats you're not stuck with the same layout/design each time.

GameplayAs I've mentioned above, there are many classes: a total of 24 divided into 4 subgroups of Warriors, Rogues, Mages, and Shamans. Each have their small differences which are fun to discover.
Seeing the trailer or the screenshots in the store page the game might seem very messy. Once you start playing though, it's not so hard to know what's going on. It might still get a bit confusing if you're playing a ranged character and you get yourself in the middle of a mob, but it's not so crazy.
To help with your questing, different types of NPCs can be freed. These NPCs follow you around and help beat monsters up. They die easily though.

ArtThe game has a nice pixel art from Oryx Design Lab (thus why it reminds me of Quest of Dungeons so much) which you might have seen in other games. It's a nice pack and it's fun to see how it's used here if you've played other games with the same one.

MusicAwesome bit music that keeps you exited while hacking everything.

OSAs of the date of this review the game is only available for windows.
However! It seems like it works perfectly with wine :)

MoreEven though the game has left early-access, the development pace is still very fast, with many updates being released. It's great to see a development team that listens to players and keep working on the product even after it could hold its own.

OverallThis is a great buy if you enjoy fast paced rogue-likes. You can play this taking advantage of the upgrade system to make advancing easier, but you can also ignore it if you enjoy permadeath experiences.
Each game doesn't take long, so it's a great game to play when you don't want to/ can't spend too long on it.

I bought this game just because it was made by the same people as SanctuaryRPG, heavy action games aren't normally something I favor but this one really impressed me.

Let's start with the good:

Really hard early on. There's people complaining about not making it past the first level out of 10. You actually can die there without being completely bad at the game.
Very gameplay dense. For a game with such simple mechanics as move and launch one of two different attacks it really does a lot with them and requires a lot of focus or you'll die.
Very gameplay focused. How many games regale you with their shiny water and copious offering of exposed breasts and then when you actually play them it's just a buggy, incomplete, boring trainwreck? You won't see that here, the focus is purely on the game itself - and the game itself is solid.
24 classes that can be unlocked fairly quickly, each of which feel and play very differently.
Steadily increasing intensity - the higher levels both have more enemies and more dangerous enemies, combat gets very chaotic very fast.
The developer is extremely active and maintains direct and regular contact with the userbase.

And now the bad:

Fairly weak graphical optimization. Even though these are SNES graphics they will still cause serious slowdown when there is extremely large amounts of activity on screen, and there almost always is later. The developer has tried fixing this, and it's usually fine but extreme activity will still cause performance problems.
Excessive graphical clutter from on kill/destroyed effects can obscure important parts of the screen.
Excessive graphical clutter from certain heroes' special abilities can obscure important parts of the screen.
Has the standard Roguelike problem at a very extreme level. You'll either die early or win in 99.9% of cases. The first time I reached floor 5 and didn't die near instantly because I got swarmed was the first time I won. Why? Because not only does the player have good tools at this point but also you start vastly outscaling the enemies, such that they do low or even single digit damage per hit while you hit for over 1,000 by endgame. You can't lose at that point no matter how bad you are even though those late game situations would otherwise be extremely dangerous.
Not a lot of enemy variety. Once you hit floor 4 or 5 you quit seeing new enemies and attacks until the end, which means once you know how you deal with the early game you know how the rest of the game works. Bosses start repeating as well, there should be 9 in a random order + the final boss at minimum, instead there are 6 + the final boss.

Overall I'd still recommend the game - it's one of the few on Steam worth full price but if you can get a sale certainly take it. I believe the developer will reduce the amount of graphical clutterr, add more content, and make the later game harder which fixes every problem on that list.

SUMMARY: A seemingly simple, brutally hard, speed roguelike that has unexpected depth and unlockables as you play.  A fast, twitchy grab-the-gold, kill-the-monster, go-as-deep-as-you-can game great for people looking for that experience.  Has a lot to offer, but takes some patience.

Overture is the classic, stereotypical dungeon crawler/roguelike boiled down to its basic - go into a dungeon as a given class, slaughter monsters, level up, grab treasure, live as long as you can.   It's for fun, fast, short-term play - though you may be surprised how long you may play it.

You pick a class, which has two different attack abilities, and wander across a randomly geneated field, battling monsters of many kinds by using your various abilities.  The monsters themselves have different abilities, though most are cannon fodder - but watch out, some more powerful versions (who have titles or are different sizes) and special monsters may surprise you.

Monsters and various chests, jars, and barrels will drop treasure.  Most of this is gold and healing and mana potions, but the occasional piece of equipment drops as well.  The equipment often has little game-changing rules and additions that can make a different and require some thought.  You may even find NPCs who join you - until the inevitable onslaughts kill them off.

Each level has a boss monster guarding a stairwell, which leads in turn to a REAL boss monster.  Defeat these much more difficult opponents and you get a bonus to mana or health, a chance to buy random equipment, and then move on to the next level.

The game at first seems overly simple and overly hard, but rewards retrying.  Classes are different - radically different.  You can learn strategies for different enemies.  Gold and scrolls (which can become gold) that you recover can unlock new classes and level up ones you already have.  There's a lot to the game, its just often concealed beneath the frenzy and the randomness.

The game's biggest flaws are erratic difficulty and limited documentation - made more painful due to the randomness.  It takes patience to get into it enough to really enjoy it.  More polishing and documentation would definitely help.

Do I reccomend it?  Like many games, the question is is it your thing."  It's not something everyone must play - it is something for people who like dungeon crawlers and action

There is a subset of gamers that really intrigues me: the type that slaves away hunched over their monitors, doing the same repetitive task over and over, with only the faintest glimmer of hope for a reward at the end of their trials. I‚Äôve never much been into games that require excessive grinding, or for the  player to invest a lot of their time for that shiny trinket that is only marginally better than the previous one, but each to their own I suppose. So, when Overture landed in my inbox I wasn‚Äôt exactly overcome with joy, but I wasn‚Äôt filled with trepidation either.

Overture is reminiscent of Realm of the Mad God, Diablo and even, to an extent, The  Binding of Isaac. It sticks you in the middle of a vast, randomly generated dungeon with hundreds of bad guys and tasks you with fighting your way out, and that‚Äôs pretty much a wrap for the game‚Äôs main features. You‚Äôll do all the usual Action RPG things, like collecting better gear and upping your stats, but, ultimately, not much changes as a result of that. Yes, you will be fighting horde after horde of bad guys, and bosses, over and over again, but that isn‚Äôt necessarily a bad thing. My dislike for repetitious games aside, Overture is a well designed, smart game that will give a certain crowd of gamers with hours of action.

While the game is certainly a one trick pony, there are lots of ways you can approach it. With 4 different classes and 24 different characters, each with their own attacks, there‚Äôs something here for every type of player. So, whether you want to be a warrior right in among the action with blood dripping from your blade, or an archer taking potshots from a safe distance, you‚Äôll find a character to suit your tastes.

Once you have chosen a class you are slung straight into the action, but not before you‚Äôve seen the handy control scheme tutorial. Playing the game is as simple as using the left mouse button to attack and the right mouse button to special attack. If you find yourself in a pinch you can hot tail it out of there by moving toward your mouse cursor, which will send you off at great speed. There‚Äôs a bit of a knack to mastering Overture‚Äòs ‚Äúhit and run‚Äù style of gameplay, but once you have you‚Äôll be tearing up countless undead, blobs and other indescribable evil doers.

Gameplay is simple and formulaic, and you‚Äôll wander through each floor looking to pick a fight with scores of different mobs at the same time, and the odd elite as well. You‚Äôll occasionally come across a mini boss which are harder to kill than normal mobs, before having to take on a much more difficult boss.

You‚Äôll be accruing experience and levelling up as you kill enemies, increasing your stats ever so slightly, whilst bolstering them further with various pieces of armour you‚Äôll receive from chests and enemies. You‚Äôll also gather companions  that you‚Äôve freed from the clutches of the enemy, and they‚Äôll fight alongside you.

If Overture was a candy bar it would be the most sugary, mouth-watering bar on the market, the kind that dilates pupils and causes synapses to fire uncontrollably. Its action is swift and meaty, with just enough danger to keep you on your toes. It also rewards even the slightest amount of skill with lashings of blood and a hail of gold coins, that is sure to intensify the ‚Äúcandy bar‚Äù effect I mentioned above.

One thing I don‚Äôt understand though is why it features no local coop, though, Overture is  the perfect game for playing on the couch with a buddy. I‚Äôll call it an oversight and not a missed opportunity, in the hope that Black Shell Games adds this feature in later.

SUMMARY: A seemingly simple, brutally hard, speed roguelike that has unexpected depth and unlockables as you play.  A fast, twitchy grab-the-gold, kill-the-monster, go-as-deep-as-you-can game great for people looking for that experience.  Has a lot to offer, but takes some patience.

Overture is the classic, stereotypical dungeon crawler/roguelike boiled down to its basic - go into a dungeon as a given class, slaughter monsters, level up, grab treasure, live as long as you can.   It's for fun, fast, short-term play - though you may be surprised how long you may play it.

You pick a class, which has two different attack abilities, and wander across a randomly geneated field, battling monsters of many kinds by using your various abilities.  The monsters themselves have different abilities, though most are cannon fodder - but watch out, some more powerful versions (who have titles or are different sizes) and special monsters may surprise you.

Monsters and various chests, jars, and barrels will drop treasure.  Most of this is gold and healing and mana potions, but the occasional piece of equipment drops as well.  The equipment often has little game-changing rules and additions that can make a different and require some thought.  You may even find NPCs who join you - until the inevitable onslaughts kill them off.

Each level has a boss monster guarding a stairwell, which leads in turn to a REAL boss monster.  Defeat these much more difficult opponents and you get a bonus to mana or health, a chance to buy random equipment, and then move on to the next level.

The game at first seems overly simple and overly hard, but rewards retrying.  Classes are different - radically different.  You can learn strategies for different enemies.  Gold and scrolls (which can become gold) that you recover can unlock new classes and level up ones you already have.  There's a lot to the game, its just often concealed beneath the frenzy and the randomness.

The game's biggest flaws are erratic difficulty and limited documentation - made more painful due to the randomness.  It takes patience to get into it enough to really enjoy it.  More polishing and documentation would definitely help.

Do I reccomend it?  Like many games, the question is is it your thing."  It's not something everyone must play - it is something for people who like dungeon crawlers and action

reviewText:
Short version:

Fun game, bullet hell, play at your own pace, always challenging
In its current state, 7.5/10, but there are constant updates improving the game.
Worth buying for the price if you wnat straight action.


Long version:

This game has a lot of mechanical similarities to games like Realm of the Mad God, and gives you a lot of room to play the way you want with an impressive variety of classes that each have multiple unique mechanics and take time to master.
You cannot play each class the same way at all, giving you the opportunity to play the game an entirely new way whenever you feel like mixing it up.

The things that this game does really well are:
- Instant chllenging action
- Boss battles every minute or so depending on how quickly you progress through each stage
- A class to suit absolutely any playstyle
- It's hard to snowball into a game breaking monster, keeping the game engaging and challenging
- Gear upgrades drop as you progress, which combines with gold drops to make killing mobs very satisfying
- Random large elite mobs in stages, making for intense moments

The things this game doesn't do so well are:
- Repetitive bosses, that all seem to follow you around the same way
- Mobs seem to all follow the same design, and you just need to back up and shoot
- Character upgrades do not make a large difference to your character, and you end up paying a lot for very little gain
- Some classes are very slow to play, which goes against the theme of the game in my opinion


Some suggestions I have for the devs are:
- Give bosses more variety. Punish the player for not playing to the weaknesses of each individual boss and give the bosses phases in which they can bevery hard to kill, or very vulnerable. The key here is making each boss difficult and unique.
- Bring more variety to the regular grind in stages. This doesn't man you have to overhaul each minion, but elite mobs may be a good focal point in improving this area. Maybe try bringing in more elite mobs that are weaker, or making it so that elite mobs always drop something, giving players an incentive to seek out this chalenge.

Class balance is something that will come with time, and looking at the patch notes I can tell that the devs are putting a lot of effort into it, and I'd like to commend them for that.

This game has a bright future, and for its low price I would definitely recommend it.

reviewText:
Overture is a Rogue-like dungeon crawler, in the vein of The Binding of Isaac, and Realm of the Mad God. You can select from up to 24 classes split into 4 divisions (Warrior, Mage, Rogue, Shaman). You must face off against hordes of undead and fantastical enemies in randomly generated dungeons, with a boss on each to progress to the next floor.

I would like to outright state that I won a key of the game in a giveaway by the Dev, but this I will try my best to make this as unbiased as possible.

Having played only 30 minutes, I'm not the most experienced player, but I believe have played enough to get a general idea of the game.
The main idea of the game is nothing original (not in a bad way), killing hordes of enemies to level up, become more powerful, and progress through the dungeon. However, it is executed very well. The game seems to be balanced rather well, with difficulty scaling throughout the floors.

Progression not only comes from levels, but also weapons, armour, shields, and rings that are randomly placed throughout floors. These will make your life a lot easier, and are a welcome addition.

This game does a lot of things very well.

1. It is a lot, and I mean a lot, of fun to play. Who doesn't love slicing through hordes of undead, becoming increasingly powerful? It's hard to stop playing after you start, and if that isn't the sign of a good game, then I don't know what is.

2. As I have mentioned before, progression through the levels, and difficulty scaling is handled very well.

3. It is an overall great Rogue-like.

I do have a few things that I think need changing, or at least a little work on.

1. The tutorial is minimal, at best. While nearly everyone is familiar with Rogue-likes, not everyone is. We get told next to nothing about how progression works, merely how to 'run fast'. The tutorial could do with at least a little bit more information for new players to the genre, incluing what the blue (mana?) bar is, and what alt-attacks can do.

2. Your character's health bar is something that is generally important to see, right? However in the middle of an encounter with a lot of enemies, that quickly gets covered by scores of numbers, the same with your character, making it nigh impossible to keep track of your location, and health. This could be improved by simply adding health and mana bars in the top left of the screen.

Overture is a game that I would recommend to my friends. While it does need a little work, it is a polished product that I would be happy to pay for.

It's a fun little game, but after a few hours or so it tends to get fairly repetitive.  I do like the multiple classes and the many characters to play as, but once they're all unlocked you'll have figured out which is your favorite and pretty much stick with that character, and only upgrade them.
And speaking of upgrades, I like that you can spend gold you've previously accumulated to make the character better, but upgrades do nothing except increase the attack power of said character.  Why there isn't an option to increase health or defense is beyond me, and it makes it so you have to play the game as a glass cannon every time.
And speaking of the repetitive nature of the game, sure, it's randomly generated, but you'll almost always fight the same enemies on the same floors, and the floor layouts are very similar.  On 1-2 there are a ton of traps.  On 1-3 there are holes with never ending slime monsters spawning from them, and so on.
Adding a mechanic where you could choose where to put your upgrade points would add a much needed level of depth to the game, and even better yet, a mechanic where you could put upgrade points in a stat when you level up during the game.
I have almost 7 hours on Overture so far, and I have enjoyed it, and I would recommend it, 5 bucks isn't very steep, and I've gotten my 5 dollars worth.  That being said, at this point, I'm wishing for a little more depth and customization, and a little more 'randomization' to break the monotony of trudging through the first few floors, fighting the same big slimes, and fighting the same bosses.

When you think of a shooter game a medieval-theme is the last thing you expect.. But that's exactly what Black Shell Games's game Overture is: a roguelike bullet hell shooter game where you're tasked to destroy legions upon legions of monsters while things constantly fly across your screen. It's a high action, fast paced game that'll leave you blinded by damage scores and the amount of chaos going on screen.

The objective of the game is to get through the floors while fighting amidst countless enemies such as skeletons, dragons, blobs, and minotaur. There's an insane variety of creatures throughout the game. Occasionally you'll see named creatures, which have the chance of giving the player special gear, health potions and a bonus in gold which also acts as your XP, doubling their values. The named creatures do have slightly more health and are often guarded by a cluster of creatures, which means they're hard to get to, but they're worth it in the end. Each creature has a comically randomly generated name like ‚ÄúHilda the Disgruntled‚Äù or something of that nature, leaving this bullet hell style game a least a little humorous.

Okay, initially, I really enjoyed this game, but...As time went on, now the novelty has worn off, I will say that I'm cooling on this game pretty rapidly. The game is still pretty good - A very fast-paced bullethell dungeoncrawler sort of deal, but...There's flaws. Pretty big ones.

First off, the visuals. Again, Initially, I quite liked them...But soon after, I discovered that the vast majority of the visuals in this were taken from an asset pack with little to no alterations. Now, I'm all for using asset packs as a base, to get your project off the ground, but...At least tweak them a bit, ya know? It makes the game look a lot more cheaply constructed, and it DOES hurt the game.

Second...The difficulty curve is unfair, to say the least. I understand a game of this nature is meant to be difficult, yes, but as it stands now it's less of a difficulty curve and more of a difficulty wall when you reach a boss, a wall you need to smash through with your face. Now, yes, a game like this that you could get through on your first try without upgrading yourself would be lunacy, but at the same time, it can be critically disheartening if you can barely progress past the first boss. Maybe I just suck, but it's pretty harsh. There's also some issues that result in some very cheap deaths, such as some of the monsters doing far too much collision damage too quickly, and very limited feedback for when you're getting hit, meaning you can die very quickly without realising you're in danger.

However...I will still give this game a borderline positive review. It's still very playable, but these two things are pretty irksome. I understand there's probably more fixes to come, so...If they changed up the graphics and made the difficulty a bit less insane, I would find this game more approachable and easier to reccomend.

So, if anyone reads my review and wonders if they should try it or not - Put basically, It's alright, and honestly, I've paid far more for far worse games. Give the Demo a try if you're unsure.

If you're more anal about knowing the ups and downs before even trying the free demo out, I'll go ahead and compile a list of Pros and Cons.

[Cons]
1. The game isn't the best in terms of customizable interface. At the present time, there is no such thing as an audio slider, so the player cannot choose how heavy SFX is over the Music.

2. Resolution is an issue. You currently only have a few options. 700xSomethingElseIDoNotKnowWhat, or Fullscreen.

3. The game can get a bit annoying with the difficulty, however, if you're used to playing games like Dark Souls, you shall be fine.

4. You could argue that there is a lack of content in the game at the moment, but you can only say that if you actually get far enough to have seen everything repeatedly in one playthrough.

[Pros]
1. The Soundtrack

2. The Soundtrack

3. Did I say the Soundtrack?

4. Not only are there 4 classes, each class has it's own six-or-so subclasses.

5. There is a general progression in your character's strength throughout the game. You can upgrade your subclasses with the gold you've amassed throughout other plays.

6. The game takes a good path on unlocking and upgrading the characters. If you've played Magicite, you probably know a good example of how annoying character goals are. In Magicite, you were required to reach a certain point, or complete a certain goal in a play to just have a CHANCE of unlocking something, whereas in Overture, you simply have to get the gold necessary to unlock/upgrade the subclass of your choice, making an easy way for the player to grow into his/her own playstyle, and find the subclass that suits it best.

Overture is most likely a grinding game, as you have to put a lot of time in this game in order to attempt to finish it. However, considering the fact that most of the indie games are not having quite a big action, Overture is very dynamic as in each floor you have to kill hordes of monsters, which in not quite easy as the number of incoming monsters is quite big and you have to pay a lot of attention to the game in order to not die, cause if you die you will have to start the game all over again from the very first Floor. Also, the Boss Battles have a certain difficulty level which makes the game progression much interesting.

So, which are the Pros for this game?

- A cute and colored design, design which changes from a floor to another
- A big variety of enemies
-  24 heroes to choose
-  The possiblity to upgrade your hero
-  The player can collect items during game progression
-  Entertaining soundtrack
- Traps which hide extra hordes of enemies

Of course, there are some Cons for this Overture as well:

- Some visual effecs might be disturbing (for example, when your hero takes damage from enemies there is a kinda strong visual impact on the screen)
- Perhaps there would've be nice if there was a story line for this game

So Overture is pretty much funny to play and I recommend this game to anyone.

I'm going to be honest. I think this is the first review I've written for a game on Steam. I don't want to be the guy who slams an independent developer and expects unrealistic quality for $5, or what it was when I first picked this up, $3. And somehow the general steam ratings for Overture has changed from mostly negatve to very positive since the last time I looked at this game, and I can't tell why.

That being said, I really want to like this game more than I do. Deep down in it, somwhere, is a really fun game. A simple twin-stick shooter with elements of Gauntlet and roguelikes is a really cool idea, and mechanically it's implemented pretty well.

However, the game is a visual mess. It's not just the blown-up pixel graphics in it - it could have masterful, highly detailed sprites, and it would have been the same. The game is often incomprehensible. It is also really hard, and grindy. Not nessecarily a bad thing, though in this case it's rather maddening. I am constantly dying to enemies I don't realize are there until it's over. There's barely any cooldown on hits to your character, and there's so much commotion on the screen, it's sometimes very difficult to tell what's going on. The game qickly turns into a churning mass of large and tiny, sometimes hard to see projectiles, friendly and enemy characters, pickups and destructible objects all over a mess of dungeon debris from everything else you've been shooting that makes objects even less distinguishable. Both taking hits and some player attacks shake the screen and blur the action. When you are on low health, the screen turns a blurry red which camoflages everything even further. Try a cleric for the first time, and then try to figure out what is going on as your large attacks seem to behave not quite consistent enough to make immediate sense, and take up a majority of the center of the screen.

BUT, I do enjoy it somwhat, as it's the only game I know of that does what it does so mechanically well. As in, shoot with swords and friendly assists, gradius-style, a bullet-hell action RPG with vastly different playstyles between characters. Think of it as a more rogelike-y, singleplayer Realm of The Mad God. It can be very cathartinc when things are going well, and there are certain parts of it that do have some charm. Considering the price point and the lack of pretense, and you should be able to forgive a lot and appreciate the core gameplay.

It's just hard to forvige such bewilderingly confusing visuals.

TL;DR: Concept is intriguing, execution is lagging.

Overture purports to draw inspiration from Zelda, Binding of Isaac, and Diablo.  I am not sure which versions of those games the creators were inspired by, because I don't recall any of them throwing hordes and hordes of monsters at you as soon as you start play.   There is no strategy, no hidden doors or secret treasures, no mazes, no...well, anything that resembles those games.  It bears a larger resemblance to Smash TV than any of the games mentioned.

The game doesn't teach you how to play- not only is there no real tutorial, the learning curve appears to be non-existent.  You select a class, the game starts, and you're off to the races.  The mechanics aren't difficult in and of themselves, but the massive number of projectiles, enemies, and other obstacles on screen remind me more of the bullet hell genre than a roguelike".
